title: Movement issues/Lag issues with no ping loss
body: So for the past two weeks any time I play it is constantly lagging when I try and move. My abilities work just sometimes I will lose control of my character movement or it won't respond for a few seconds. At first, I thought my mouse was broken but it appears to be a connection issue. I have tried to resolve it by fixing DNS settings and all kinds of other 'solutions" but had no success. Anyone else having this problem?

replies.body:
This sounds like very typical symptoms of *packet loss*, which occurs when there are drops in your connection along the way to the servers. Before we take a deep look into your routing to the servers, I recommend configuring your network to align with the settings we suggest inside our [connection guide.](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues)

Let me know if those steps helped.

I checked the connection guides and did the suggested connection test this was the main concerning red flag:

> Your ISP's DNS server returns IP addresses even for domain names which should not resolve. Instead of an error, the DNS server returns an address of 104.239.213.7, which does not resolve.
> 
> There are several possible explanations for this behavior. The most likely cause is that the ISP is attempting to profit from 
> customer's typos by presenting advertisements in response to bad requests, but it could also be due to an error or misconfiguration in the DNS server.
> 
> The big problem with this behavior is that it can potentially break any network application which relies on DNS properly returning an error when a name does not exist.
> 
> The following lists your DNS server's behavior in more detail.
> 
> www.{random}.com is mapped to 104.239.213.7.
> www.{random}.org is mapped to 104.239.213.7.
> fubar.{random}.com is correctly reported as an error.
> www.yahoo.cmo [sic] is mapped to 104.239.213.7.
> nxdomain.{random}.netalyzr.icsi.berkeley.edu is correctly reported as an error.
> 

I've changed my DNS address and even used an application to find the best DNS server for my connection. Nothing seems to resolve the issue. I'm afraid this might be an issue with my ISP, and that I cannot resolve without having to deal with the terrible ISP "run around". Thank you for your assistance and if there is anything else I should try, please let me know.

I definitely suspect there may be issues along your ISP's network routing to the servers, since you're still having issues. I'd like to see where this happens by taking a look at a traceroute. You can grab one of these by using a network app called [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net/) and plugging in **104.160.131.1** as the focus address before you start the trace. After it has run for about 5 minutes, export the results as text and paste them in a reply here.

If you encounter issues running that trace, let me know.

I'm on a Mac so I found another program(Nmap/Zenmap) to get a traceroute.

Ah, I didn't realize you were on a Mac. This traceroute shows some basic info, but it lacks some of the data necessary to get action taken. We usually have Mac players test using Pingplotter, which you can grab [here.](https://www.pingplotter.com/download/mac/)

Before starting the trace, set your test parameters to a 5-minute focus time with a 1-second trace interval. You can then plug in **104.160.131.1** into the host field and start the trace. After it has finished, [grab a screenshot](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201361) of all the results and upload the screenshot to [Imgur](https://imgur.com/) before linking it to me.

Let me know if you run into any issues along the way.

It looks like you have a big spike in latency on the second hop outside your home network. This likely may be where the issue happens, but this traceroute didn't catch any packet loss. You may want to reach out to your ISP with this screenshot so they can start an investigation.

Let me know if you have any questions.
KK. Thanks a lot man you've been a big help.
